sections.doc_:
## Introduction

An autocomplete-enabled input field suggests completed results corresponding to the user input as they type into the input field. 
This feature can help the user to carry out their task more quickly.
Data can either be fetched from a JSON endpoint or locally from amp-state.

Introduction

An autocomplete-enabled input field suggests completed results corresponding to the user input as they type into the input field. This feature can help the user to carry out their task more quickly. Data can either be fetched from a JSON endpoint or locally from amp-state.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Introduction

An autocomplete-enabled input field suggests completed results corresponding to the user input as they type into the input field. 
This feature can help the user to carry out their task more quickly.
Data can either be fetched from a JSON endpoint or locally from amp-state.

sections.doc_: Optional: `amp-bind` is needed for dynamically changing the data source of an `amp-autocomplete`.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Optional: `amp-bind` is needed for dynamically changing the data source of an `amp-autocomplete`.

sections.doc_: Optional: `amp-mustache` is needed for rich-content templating and client-side rendering of form responses.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Optional: `amp-mustache` is needed for rich-content templating and client-side rendering of form responses.

sections.code: Basic usage

sections.doc_:
## Basic usage

An `amp-autocomplete` must always be nested in a form and have an **input field** specified with an `input` or `textarea` tag and a datasource. 
When a user types into this input field, relevant suggestions will automatically appear below the input field.

A **datasource** must be a JSON object containing an array property `items`, and can be specified inline with a child `script type="application/json"` tag, or a server endpoint specified with a `src` attribute.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Basic usage

An `amp-autocomplete` must always be nested in a form and have an **input field** specified with an `input` or `textarea` tag and a datasource. 
When a user types into this input field, relevant suggestions will automatically appear below the input field.

A **datasource** must be a JSON object containing an array property `items`, and can be specified inline with a child `script type="application/json"` tag, or a server endpoint specified with a `src` attribute.

sections.doc_: Alternatively, a datasource can also be provided as remote data through the `src` attribute.
sections.normalizedDoc_: Alternatively, a datasource can also be provided as remote data through the `src` attribute.

sections.doc_:
## Dynamic `src`

The content of an `amp-autocomplete` can be changed dynamically by modifying its `src` value using `amp-bind`.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Dynamic `src`

The content of an `amp-autocomplete` can be changed dynamically by modifying its `src` value using `amp-bind`.

sections.doc_: ## Suggesting rich content More complicated data can be passed into autocompleted with an array of JsonObjects in "items". [sourcecode:json] { "items" : [ { "city" : "Albany", "state" : "New York", "areaCode" : 518, "population" : 98251 }, { "city" : "Annapolis", "state" : "Maryland", "areaCode" : 410, "population" : 39321 }, { "city" : "Trenton", "state" : "New Jersey", "areaCode" : 609, "population" : 84964 } ] } [/sourcecode] The corresponding display of these data in the `amp-autocomplete` can be specified through a template. [sourcecode:html] [/sourcecode] By default, `amp-autocomplete` will suggest items by matching on the "value" property of each JsonObject, but for more specified data, an attribute `filter-value` can be provided to signify the appropriate property to search on. In the above example, we will want to search on the property `name`, because that is what the user will most likely search for.
sections.code: Error!
sections.preview: Error!
sections.normalizedDoc_: ## Suggesting rich content More complicated data can be passed into autocompleted with an array of JsonObjects in "items". ```json { "items" : [ { "city" : "Albany", "state" : "New York", "areaCode" : 518, "population" : 98251 }, { "city" : "Annapolis", "state" : "Maryland", "areaCode" : 410, "population" : 39321 }, { "city" : "Trenton", "state" : "New Jersey", "areaCode" : 609, "population" : 84964 } ] } ``` The corresponding display of these data in the `amp-autocomplete` can be specified through a template. ```html ``` By default, `amp-autocomplete` will suggest items by matching on the "value" property of each JsonObject, but for more specified data, an attribute `filter-value` can be provided to signify the appropriate property to search on. In the above example, we will want to search on the property `name`, because that is what the user will most likely search for.

sections.doc_:
## Displaying default items

Default suggestions for an `amp-autocomplete` can be displayed on user `focus` using rich content templating and the `min-characters` attribute on `amp-autocomplete`.

Additionally, because the `data-disabled` attribute on a template-rendered item allows it to be displayed but not searched against or selected, it can be useful for constructing a "header" within the results list that can serve to organize selectable items into categories. In the example below, "Popular groceries" acts as an example of the disabled item because it is not an item that you actually want to treat as a product.

sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Displaying default items

Default suggestions for an `amp-autocomplete` can be displayed on user `focus` using rich content templating and the `min-characters` attribute on `amp-autocomplete`.

Additionally, because the `data-disabled` attribute on a template-rendered item allows it to be displayed but not searched against or selected, it can be useful for constructing a "header" within the results list that can serve to organize selectable items into categories. In the example below, "Popular groceries" acts as an example of the disabled item because it is not an item that you actually want to treat as a product.

sections.doc_:
## Displaying suggestions inline

Suggestions can be triggered on a specified character token in an `amp-autocomplete` for multiple autosuggestions in a single input by using the `inline` attribute.
The token for triggering the autosuggestion must be the provided value for the `inline` attribute. For example, if `inline="+"`, then when the `+` token is entered by the user,
any relevant suggestions will be displayed. Otherwise, the field will behave the same as an unenhanced input field. The `inline` attribute does not support the empty string, 
or `""` as a legitimate token value on `amp-autocomplete`.
sections.code: Error!
sections.preview: Error!
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Displaying suggestions inline

Suggestions can be triggered on a specified character token in an `amp-autocomplete` for multiple autosuggestions in a single input by using the `inline` attribute.
The token for triggering the autosuggestion must be the provided value for the `inline` attribute. For example, if `inline="+"`, then when the `+` token is entered by the user,
any relevant suggestions will be displayed. Otherwise, the field will behave the same as an unenhanced input field. The `inline` attribute does not support the empty string, 
or `""` as a legitimate token value on `amp-autocomplete`.

sections.doc_:
## Specifying query parameters

User inputs can be passed to a statically generated endpoint when the `query` attribute is paired with the `src` attribute.

For example if a `src="https://example.com` and `query="q"`, then a user who types in `abc` will get the fetch JSON result from `https://example.com?q=abc`.
sections.normalizedDoc_:
## Specifying query parameters

User inputs can be passed to a statically generated endpoint when the `query` attribute is paired with the `src` attribute.

For example if a `src="https://example.com` and `query="q"`, then a user who types in `abc` will get the fetch JSON result from `https://example.com?q=abc`.
